E1001.usedFor: Single `&` or `|` without being doubled, other invalid characters
E1001.howToFix: Remove or replace the illegal character from your source code. EZ only supports standard ASCII characters for code.

E1002.howToFix: Use `||` for logical OR operations, not a single `|` character.

E1003.howToFix: Add `*/` to close your multi-line comment.

E1004.howToFix: Add a closing `"` to terminate your string literal.

E1005.howToFix: Add a closing `'` to terminate your character literal.

E1006.howToFix: Use valid escape sequences: `\n`, `\t`, `\\`, `\"`, `\r`. Remove or fix the invalid escape sequence.

E1007.usedFor: Unknown escape like `\x` in char literal
E1007.example: invalid escape sequence '\x' in character literal
E1007.howToFix: Use valid escape sequences in character literals: `\n`, `\t`, `\\`, `\'`, `\r`.

E1008.howToFix: Character literals must contain exactly one character. Use `' '` for space or another valid character.

E1009.example: character literal must contain exactly one character
E1009.howToFix: Character literals can only contain one character. Use a string (`"..."`) for multiple characters.

E1010.example: invalid number format: multiple decimal points
E1010.howToFix: Check your number literal for typos. Ensure it follows valid integer or float format.

E1011.example: consecutive underscores not allowed in numeric literals
E1011.howToFix: Use single underscores as separators in numbers: `1_000_000` not `1__000`.

E1012.example: numeric literal cannot start with underscore
E1012.howToFix: Numbers cannot start with underscore. Use `1_000` not `_1000`.

E1013.example: numeric literal cannot end with underscore
E1013.howToFix: Numbers cannot end with underscore. Use `1_000` not `1000_`.

E1014.example: underscore cannot appear immediately before decimal point
E1014.howToFix: Remove underscore before the decimal point. Use `3.14` not `3_.14`.

E1015.example: underscore cannot appear immediately after decimal point
E1015.howToFix: Remove underscore after the decimal point. Use `3.14` not `3._14`.

E1016.example: invalid number format: decimal point must be followed by digits
E1016.howToFix: Add digits after the decimal point. Use `3.0` not `3.`.

E2001.usedFor: Token found where another was expected
E2001.howToFix: Check your syntax around the reported location. You may have a typo or missing punctuation.

E2002.howToFix: Add the expected token (semicolon, brace, parenthesis, etc.) at the indicated location.

E2003.howToFix: Provide an expression where expected. Check for incomplete statements or missing values.

E2004.howToFix: Add a closing `}` to match your opening brace.

E2005.howToFix: Add a closing `)` to match your opening parenthesis.

E2006.howToFix: Add a closing `]` to match your opening bracket.

E2007.howToFix: Add `}` to close your string interpolation `${...}`.

E2008.usedFor: Assignment to non-assignable (not identifier, index, or member)
E2008.example: invalid assignment target: cannot assign to *ast.IntegerValue
E2008.howToFix: You can only assign to variables, array elements, or struct fields. Check the left side of your assignment.

E2009.example: file-scoped 'using' must come before all declarations
E2009.howToFix: Move your `using` statement to the top of the file, before any variable or function declarations.

E2010.example: cannot use module 'math' before importing it
E2010.howToFix: Import a module with `import @module` before using it with `use @module`.

E2011.example: const 'x' must be initialized with a value
E2011.howToFix: Constants must be initialized. Add `= value` to your const declaration.

E2012.howToFix: Rename one of the duplicate parameters to have a unique name.

E2013.howToFix: Rename one of the duplicate struct fields to have a unique name.

E2014.howToFix: Add a type annotation to your parameter: `do foo(x int)` not `do foo(x)`.

E2015.howToFix: Add a return type after the arrow: `do foo() -> int { ... }`.

E2016.example: enum 'Status' must have at least one value
E2016.howToFix: Add at least one value to your enum declaration.

E2017.example: unexpected trailing comma in array literal
E2017.howToFix: Remove the trailing comma from your array literal: `{1, 2, 3}` not `{1, 2, 3,}`.

E2018.example: unexpected trailing comma in function call
E2018.howToFix: Remove the trailing comma from your function call: `foo(1, 2)` not `foo(1, 2,)`.

E2019.example: function declarations are not allowed inside functions
E2019.howToFix: Move the inner function outside of the outer function. EZ does not allow nested function definitions.

E2020.example: 'temp' is a reserved keyword and cannot be used as a variable name
E2020.howToFix: Choose a different name. Reserved words like `if`, `for`, `while`, etc. cannot be used as variable names.

E2021.example: 'len' is a reserved keyword and cannot be used as a function name
E2021.howToFix: Choose a different function name. Built-in names and reserved words cannot be used.

E2022.example: 'int' is a reserved keyword and cannot be used as a type name
E2022.howToFix: Choose a different type name. Built-in types and reserved words cannot be used.

E2023.example: 'x' is already declared in this scope
E2023.howToFix: Rename one of the duplicate declarations or remove the redundant one.

E2024.howToFix: Use a valid type name: `int`, `float`, `string`, `bool`, `char`, or a defined struct/enum name.

E2025.example: expected integer for array size, got STRING
E2025.howToFix: Array size must be a positive integer literal: `var arr [5]int` not `var arr [x]int`.

E2026.example: enum type attributes must be primitive types (int, float, or string), got 'Custom'
E2026.howToFix: Enum base types must be primitive: `int`, `float`, or `string`.

E2027.howToFix: Check your integer literal for invalid characters or overflow.

E2028.howToFix: Check your float literal for invalid characters or formatting issues.

E2029.howToFix: Provide a valid identifier (name) where expected. Names must start with a letter or underscore.

E2030.howToFix: Add a block statement `{ ... }` where expected.

E2031.example: string enums require explicit values for all members
E2031.howToFix: String enums need explicit values: `const Colors enum { RED = "red", BLUE = "blue" }`.

E2032.usedFor: Declaring const array without explicit size
E2032.example: const array must have a fixed size
E2032.howToFix: Constant arrays must have a fixed size: `const arr [3]int = {1, 2, 3}`.

E2033.usedFor: Using a reserved keyword or builtin name as a function parameter
E2033.howToFix: Choose a different parameter name that is not a reserved keyword or builtin.

E2034.usedFor: Using a reserved keyword or builtin name as a struct field
E2034.howToFix: Choose a different field name that is not a reserved keyword or builtin.

E2035.usedFor: Using a reserved keyword or builtin name as an enum value
E2035.howToFix: Choose a different enum value name that is not a reserved keyword or builtin.

E2036.usedFor: Import statement inside a function or block
E2036.example: import statement must be at file level, not inside a function
E2036.howToFix: Move the import statement to the top of the file, outside of any function or block.

E2037.usedFor: Using a reserved keyword or builtin type as a struct name
E2037.howToFix: Choose a different struct name that is not a reserved keyword or builtin type.

E2038.usedFor: Using a reserved keyword or builtin type as an enum name
E2038.howToFix: Choose a different enum name that is not a reserved keyword or builtin type.

E2039.usedFor: Declaring a required parameter after an optional parameter with a default value
E2039.example: required parameter 'y' cannot come after parameter 'x' which has a default value
E2039.howToFix: Move required parameters before parameters with default values. Required parameters must come first.

E2040.usedFor: Declaring a mutable (&) parameter with a default value
E2040.example: mutable parameter '&p' cannot have a default value
E2040.howToFix: Remove either the `&` modifier or the default value. Mutable parameters cannot have defaults.

E2041.usedFor: When statement without a default case (unless using #strict with enum)
E2041.example: when statement requires a default case
E2041.howToFix: Add a `default { }` case to handle values not covered by `is` cases, or use `#strict` with an enum.

E2042.usedFor: #strict when statement that includes a default case
E2042.example: strict when statement cannot have a default case
E2042.howToFix: Remove the `default` case. Strict when statements must cover all enum values explicitly.

E2043.usedFor: Same value appears in multiple `is` cases
E2043.example: duplicate case value '1' in when statement
E2043.howToFix: Remove the duplicate case value. Each value can only appear once in a when statement.

E2044.usedFor: Using a float value as a when condition
E2044.example: float type not allowed in when statement
E2044.howToFix: Use `if/or/otherwise` for float comparisons instead of `when`. Floats are not exact and shouldn't be used for pattern matching.

E2045.usedFor: #strict attribute on a when statement that doesn't match an enum
E2045.example: #strict can only be used with enum when statements
E2045.howToFix: Remove the `#strict` attribute. It can only be used when the when condition is an enum value.

E2046.usedFor: #strict when statement that doesn't cover all enum values
E2046.example: strict when statement missing case for 'Status.PENDING'
E2046.howToFix: Add an `is` case for each enum value. Strict when statements must be exhaustive.

E2047.usedFor: Using a type name instead of a variable as when condition
E2047.example: when condition must be a value, not a type name 'int'
E2047.howToFix: Use a variable or expression that evaluates to a value, not a type name.

E2048.usedFor: Using a boolean value or expression as when condition
E2048.example: when condition cannot be a boolean. Use if/or/otherwise instead
E2048.howToFix: Use `if/or/otherwise` for boolean conditions. The `when` statement is for pattern matching on discrete values.

E2049.example: when condition cannot be nil. Use if/otherwise to check for nil
E2049.howToFix: Use `if value == nil { } otherwise { }` to check for nil values.

E2050.usedFor: Using an array or map as when condition
E2050.example: when condition cannot be an array or map
E2050.howToFix: Arrays and maps cannot be used as when conditions. Use `if/or/otherwise` for collection comparisons.

E2051.usedFor: Using #suppress attribute on non-function declarations (except file-level #suppress(ALL))
E2051.example: #suppress can only be applied to function declarations or at file level with ALL
E2051.howToFix: Move the #suppress attribute to a function declaration, or use #suppress(ALL) at the top of the file to suppress all warnings in that file.

E2052.usedFor: Using #suppress with an invalid or unknown warning code
E2052.howToFix: Use a valid warning code with #suppress. Valid codes are W1001-W4001, or use ALL to suppress all warnings.

E3001.example: type mismatch: expected int, got string
E3001.howToFix: Ensure the value type matches the expected type. Use explicit type conversion if needed.

E3002.howToFix: Use an operator that is valid for this type. For example, you cannot use `*` on strings.

E3003.example: index must be an integer, got STRING
E3003.howToFix: Array/string indices must be integers. Convert your index to an integer.

E3004.usedFor: Assigning wrong type to string index
E3004.example: can only assign character to string index, got INTEGER
E3004.howToFix: The assigned value must match the array's element type.

E3005.example: cannot convert "abc" to int: invalid integer format
E3005.howToFix: The value cannot be converted to an integer. Check the source value type.

E3006.example: cannot convert "abc" to float: invalid float format
E3006.howToFix: The value cannot be converted to a float. Check the source value type.

E3007.howToFix: Arrays cannot be converted to scalar values. Access individual elements instead.

E3008.howToFix: Define the type before using it, or check for typos in the type name.

E3009.howToFix: Ensure all field types in your struct are defined before the struct declaration.

E3010.howToFix: Define the parameter type or check for typos.

E3011.howToFix: Define the return type or check for typos.

E3012.example: return type mismatch: expected int, got string
E3012.howToFix: Ensure your return value matches the declared return type.

E3013.example: wrong number of return values: expected 2, got 1
E3013.howToFix: Return the correct number of values as declared in the function signature.

E3014.example: incompatible types for operator '+': INTEGER and STRING
E3014.howToFix: Both operands must be compatible types. Convert one operand to match the other.

E3015.howToFix: Only functions can be called. Check that you're calling a function, not a variable.

E3016.example: index operator not supported for STRUCT
E3016.howToFix: Only arrays, strings, and maps can be indexed with `[]`.

E3017.example: for_each requires array or string, got INTEGER
E3017.howToFix: Only arrays, strings, maps, and ranges can be used in `for_each` loops.

E3018.example: array type requires value in {} format, got scalar
E3018.howToFix: Initialize arrays with array literals: `{1, 2, 3}` not a single value.

E3019.usedFor: Assigning signed int to unsigned int type
E3019.example: cannot assign signed type 'int' to unsigned type 'uint'
E3019.howToFix: Cannot assign a signed type to an unsigned variable. Use explicit conversion or change the variable type.

E3020.usedFor: Assigning negative literal to unsigned int type
E3020.example: cannot assign negative value -5 to unsigned type 'uint'
E3020.howToFix: Unsigned types cannot hold negative values. Use a signed type or ensure the value is non-negative.

E3021.usedFor: Assigning a value outside the byte range (0-255) to a byte variable
E3021.example: byte value must be between 0 and 255, got 300
E3021.howToFix: Ensure the value assigned to a byte is within the valid range of 0 to 255.

E3022.usedFor: Array literal for byte array contains a value outside 0-255
E3022.example: byte array element must be between 0 and 255, got 256
E3022.howToFix: Ensure all elements in a byte array literal are within the valid range of 0 to 255.

E3023.usedFor: Passing a const variable to a function parameter declared with &
E3023.example: cannot pass immutable variable 'config' to mutable parameter '&p'
E3023.howToFix: Use a `temp` variable instead of `const`, or remove the `&` from the parameter if mutation is not needed.

E3024.usedFor: Function declares return type but has no return statement
E3024.example: function 'calculate' must return a value of type 'int'
E3024.howToFix: Add a return statement with a value matching the declared return type.

E3025.usedFor: Assigning a value outside the byte range (0-255) to a byte variable
E3025.example: byte value must be between 0 and 255, got 300
E3025.howToFix: Ensure the value assigned to a byte is within the valid range of 0 to 255.

E3026.usedFor: Array literal for byte array contains a value outside 0-255
E3026.example: byte array element must be between 0 and 255, got 256
E3026.howToFix: Ensure all elements in a byte array literal are within the valid range of 0 to 255.

E3027.usedFor: Passing a const variable to a function parameter declared with &
E3027.example: cannot pass immutable variable 'config' to mutable parameter '&p'
E3027.howToFix: Use a `temp` variable instead of `const`, or remove the `&` from the parameter if mutation is not needed.

E3028.usedFor: Enum declaration with members of different types
E3028.example: enum members must all have the same type
E3028.howToFix: Ensure all enum members have the same underlying type (all ints or all strings).

E3029.usedFor: Using a float-based enum as a map key
E3029.example: float-based enum cannot be used as map key
E3029.howToFix: Use an int or string-based enum for map keys. Float-based enums cannot be used as map keys due to precision issues.

E4001.howToFix: Declare the variable before using it, or check for typos in the variable name.

E4002.howToFix: Define the function before calling it, import the module containing it, or check for typos.

E4003.howToFix: Check that the field exists on the struct. Verify the field name spelling.

E4004.example: enum value 'BAR' not found in enum 'Status'
E4004.howToFix: Use a value that exists in the enum definition.

E4005.howToFix: Check that the function or constant exists in the module. Verify the name spelling.

E4006.howToFix: Define the struct before using `new` with it.

E4007.howToFix: Add `import @modulename` at the top of your file.

E4008.example: function 'len' found in multiple modules: arrays, strings
E4008.howToFix: Use the module prefix to disambiguate: `module.function()` instead of just `function()`.

E4009.example: Program must define a main() function
E4009.howToFix: Add a `do main() { }` function as the entry point for your program.

E4010.example: nil reference: cannot access member 'x' of nil
E4010.howToFix: Check that the value is not nil before accessing members. Use conditional checks.

E4011.example: member access not supported on type INTEGER
E4011.howToFix: Only structs and modules support member access with `.`. Check the value type.

E5001.howToFix: Check that the divisor is not zero before dividing.

E5002.howToFix: Check that the divisor is not zero before using modulo.

E5003.example: index out of bounds: attempted to access index 100, but valid range is 0-4
E5003.howToFix: Ensure your index is within valid range: `0` to `len(array) - 1`.

E5004.example: index out of bounds: array is empty (length 0)
E5004.howToFix: Check that the collection is not empty before indexing.

E5005.example: nil reference: cannot use nil with operator '+'
E5005.howToFix: Check that the value is not nil before performing operations on it.

E5006.example: cannot assign to immutable variable 'x' (declared as const)
E5006.howToFix: Use `var` instead of `const` if you need to modify the variable, or remove the assignment.

E5007.example: cannot modify immutable array (declared as const)
E5007.howToFix: Use `var` instead of `const` for the array if you need to modify it.

E5008.example: wrong number of arguments: expected 3, got 2
E5008.howToFix: Pass the correct number of arguments as defined in the function signature.

E5009.howToFix: `break` can only be used inside `for`, `while`, or `for_each` loops.

E5010.howToFix: `continue` can only be used inside `for`, `while`, or `for_each` loops.

E5011.example: return value from function not used (use @ignore to discard)
E5011.howToFix: Assign the return value to a variable or explicitly ignore it if not needed.

E5012.howToFix: Ensure the number of variables matches the number of values in multiple assignment.

E5013.howToFix: Range start must be an integer: `0..10` not `"a"..10`.

E5014.howToFix: Range end must be an integer: `0..10` not `0.."z"`.

E5015.usedFor: Using ++ or -- on a non-variable expression
E5015.example: postfix operator requires an identifier, got literal
E5015.howToFix: Use postfix operators (++ or --) only on variables, not on literals or expressions.

E5016.usedFor: Attempting to modify a parameter not declared with &
E5016.howToFix: Add `&` before the parameter name to make it mutable: `do foo(&p Person)` instead of `do foo(p Person)`.

E5017.usedFor: Attempting to modify a field of a struct instance that was declared as const (immutable)
E5017.example: cannot modify field of immutable struct 'p' (declared as const)
E5017.howToFix: Use `temp` instead of `const` when declaring a struct instance that you need to modify.

E5018.usedFor: Function calls itself too many times without returning
E5018.howToFix: Add a base case to your recursive function to stop the recursion, or rewrite using iteration.

E5019.usedFor: Using a non-integer value as the step argument in range()
E5019.example: range step must be an integer, got FLOAT
E5019.howToFix: Use an integer value for the step argument in range(). Convert to int if needed.

E5020.usedFor: Using `in range()` with a non-integer value
E5020.example: cannot check if float is in range: value must be integer
E5020.howToFix: Convert the value to an integer before checking if it's in a range, or use comparison operators instead.

E5021.usedFor: Program explicitly called `panic()` to terminate execution
E5021.howToFix: Investigate the panic message to understand why the program terminated. Fix the underlying condition that caused the panic.

E5022.usedFor: An `assert()` check failed because the condition evaluated to false
E5022.howToFix: Check that the asserted condition holds true. Review the values being tested and fix the logic that caused the assertion to fail.

E6001.usedFor: A imports B, B imports A
E6001.example: circular import detected: a.ez -> b.ez -> a.ez
E6001.howToFix: Restructure your modules to remove the circular dependency. Consider creating a shared module.

E6002.howToFix: Check the module path and name. Ensure the module file exists.

E6003.howToFix: Check the module file for syntax errors.

E6004.example: failed to load module 'foo': permission denied
E6004.howToFix: Check file permissions and ensure the module file is readable.

E6005.usedFor: Module declaration name differs from directory name
E6005.example: module name 'foo' does not match directory name 'bar'
E6005.howToFix: The `module` declaration must match the directory name containing the file.

E6006.usedFor: Multiple files in same directory declare different module names
E6006.example: files in directory declare conflicting module names: 'foo' vs 'bar'
E6006.howToFix: All files in a directory must declare the same module name.

E6007.usedFor: Attempting to import internal module from outside its parent package
E6007.example: cannot import internal module 'pkg/internal/util' from outside 'pkg'
E6007.howToFix: Files in `internal/` directories can only be imported by files in the same package.

E6008.usedFor: Attempting to modify a module's exported member
E6008.howToFix: Module-level constants and exports cannot be reassigned from outside the module.

E6009.usedFor: Accessing private (unexported) member from another module
E6009.example: cannot access private member 'helper' from outside module 'utils'
E6009.howToFix: Private members (lowercase names) cannot be accessed from outside the module. Use exported members instead.

E7001.usedFor: Wrong number of args to stdlib function
E7001.howToFix: Check the function signature and pass the correct number of arguments.

E7002.howToFix: Pass an array to this function.

E7003.howToFix: Pass a string to this function.

E7004.howToFix: Pass an integer to this function.

E7005.howToFix: Pass an integer or float to this function.

E7006.howToFix: Pass a function reference to this function.

E7007.howToFix: Pass a map to this function.

E7008.howToFix: Pass a boolean (`true` or `false`) to this function.

E7009.howToFix: Pass a character to this function.

E7010.usedFor: Argument value out of expected range or format
E7010.howToFix: Check the function documentation for valid argument values.

E7011.howToFix: Pass a non-negative value (zero or positive).

E7013.howToFix: Pass a non-empty collection or string.

E7014.howToFix: Ensure the value can be converted to the target type.

E7015.howToFix: `len()` only works on arrays, strings, and maps.

E7016.usedFor: I/O operation attempts to access a non-existent file or directory
E7016.example: file or directory not found: open /path/to/missing.txt: no such file or directory
E7016.howToFix: Verify the file path is correct and the file exists. Use `io.exists()` to check if a path exists before attempting operations.

E7017.usedFor: Program lacks sufficient permissions for file operation
E7017.howToFix: Check file and directory permissions. Ensure the program has appropriate read/write/execute permissions.

E7018.example: io.remove() cannot remove directories, use io.remove_dir() instead
E7018.howToFix: Use `io.remove_dir()` to remove empty directories or `io.remove_all()` for recursive deletion.

E7019.example: io.remove_dir() can only remove directories, use io.remove() for files
E7019.howToFix: Use `io.remove()` to remove files. Use `io.is_file()` to check if a path is a file.

E7020.usedFor: `io.remove_all()` called on root or home directory
E7020.example: io.remove_all() cannot remove root or home directory for safety
E7020.howToFix: Never attempt to recursively delete root or home directories. Use more specific paths for deletion operations.

E7021.usedFor: `io.copy()` called with a directory as the source path
E7021.example: io.copy() cannot copy directories, only files
E7021.howToFix: Use `io.copy()` only for individual files. For directory copying, iterate through contents and copy files individually.

E7022.usedFor: Attempting to create a file or directory that already exists
E7022.example: file or directory already exists: mkdir /existing/dir: file exists
E7022.howToFix: Check if the file/directory exists with `io.exists()` before creation. Choose a different name or remove the existing one first.

E7023.example: directory not empty: remove /path/to/dir: directory not empty
E7023.howToFix: Remove all files and subdirectories first, or use `io.remove_all()` for recursive deletion (use with caution).

E7024.usedFor: Setting, getting, or unsetting an environment variable fails
E7024.example: environment variable operation failed: invalid variable name
E7024.howToFix: Ensure environment variable names are valid (no `=` or null characters) and not empty.

E7025.usedFor: System cannot determine the current working directory
E7025.example: failed to get current directory: getwd: no such file or directory
E7025.howToFix: Ensure the current working directory exists and you have permission to access it.

E7026.usedFor: Program cannot change to the specified directory
E7026.example: failed to change directory: chdir /nonexistent: no such file or directory
E7026.howToFix: Verify the target directory exists with `io.exists()` and `io.is_dir()`. Check that you have execute permission on the directory.

E7027.howToFix: Verify your system's hostname configuration. Check `/etc/hostname` on Linux systems.

E7028.usedFor: System cannot determine the current user's username
E7028.howToFix: Verify the current user exists in the system's user database. Check `/etc/passwd` on Linux systems.

E7029.usedFor: System cannot determine the user's home directory
E7029.example: io.expand_path(): failed to get home directory
E7029.howToFix: Ensure the HOME environment variable is set and the user's home directory exists.

E7030.usedFor: os.exec() or os.exec_output() cannot find the specified command
E7030.howToFix: Verify the command exists and is in your PATH. Use the full path to the executable if needed.

E7031.usedFor: os.exec() or os.exec_output() command returned a non-zero exit code
E7031.example: os.exec_output(): command failed with exit code 1
E7031.howToFix: Check the command's error output for details. The command may have failed due to invalid arguments or permissions.

E7032.usedFor: Passing a negative value to `sleep_seconds()`, `sleep_milliseconds()`, or `sleep_nanoseconds()`
E7032.howToFix: Pass a non-negative value as the sleep duration. Use 0 if you don't want to sleep.

E7033.usedFor: Converting a float to int when the value is too large, NaN, or Infinity
E7033.example: int(): float value too large for int64
E7033.howToFix: Ensure the float value is within the valid int64 range before converting. Check for NaN/Infinity values first.

E7040.usedFor: Empty string passed as a file path to an I/O function
E7040.howToFix: Ensure path variables are initialized before use. Add validation to check for empty paths before I/O operations.

E7041.usedFor: File path contains a null byte character (security risk)
E7041.howToFix: Remove null bytes from the path string. Sanitize user input before using it in file paths.

E7042.usedFor: `io.read_file()` or similar called with a directory path
E7042.example: io.read_file(): cannot read directory as file
E7042.howToFix: Use `io.read_dir()` to list directory contents. Verify the path points to a file with `io.is_file()`.

E7043.usedFor: io.glob() called with an invalid pattern
E7043.howToFix: Check your glob pattern syntax. Valid patterns use `*` (any chars), `?` (single char), `**` (recursive), and `[...]` (character class).

E7050.usedFor: Attempting to perform an operation on an already-closed file handle
E7050.howToFix: Track file handle state and avoid operations after closing. Re-open the file if you need to perform more operations.

E7099.usedFor: Catch-all for I/O failures not covered by more specific error codes
E7099.example: io error during write: disk full
E7099.howToFix: Read the detailed error message for the specific cause. Check available disk space and verify file system is not read-only.

E8001.howToFix: Pass a non-negative number to `math.sqrt()`. Use `math.abs()` first if needed.

E8002.howToFix: Pass a positive number (greater than zero) to logarithm functions.

E8003.howToFix: Ensure the input is within the valid range for the trigonometric function.

E8005.howToFix: Use a smaller input value. Factorial of 20 is the maximum for 64-bit integers.

E8006.example: random.int() range is invalid: max must be greater than min
E8006.howToFix: Ensure the minimum is less than the maximum in random range functions. For `random.int(max)`, max must be > 0.

E8007.usedFor: math.map_range() called with equal in_min and in_max values
E8007.example: math.map_range() requires in_min != in_max to avoid division by zero
E8007.howToFix: Ensure in_min and in_max are different values to avoid division by zero.

E9001.usedFor: Operations on empty array like pop, shift, min, max, avg
E9001.howToFix: Check that the array is not empty before performing the operation using `len(arr) > 0`.

E9002.howToFix: This operation requires an array of numbers (integers or floats).

E9003.howToFix: Range step must be non-zero. Use a positive or negative integer.

E9004.example: arrays.chunk() size must be greater than zero
E9004.howToFix: Chunk size must be greater than zero.

E9005.howToFix: Ensure the start value is less than or equal to the end value. Swap the arguments if needed.

E9020.usedFor: Using a non-hashable type (array, map, struct) as a map key
E9020.example: type 'array' cannot be used as map key
E9020.howToFix: Map keys must be hashable types: `string`, `int`, `float`, `bool`, or `char`. Convert the value to a hashable type.

E10001.howToFix: Pass a non-negative integer as the repeat count.

E10002.usedFor: random.choice() or random.sample() called on an empty array
E10002.example: random.choice(): cannot select from empty array
E10002.howToFix: Ensure the array has at least one element before selecting. Use `len(arr) > 0` to check first.

E10003.usedFor: Accessing a character at an invalid index in a string
E10003.example: string index out of bounds: index 10 on string of length 5
E10003.howToFix: Ensure the index is within the valid range (0 to len(str)-1). Check string length before indexing.

E10004.usedFor: Attempting to index an empty string
E10004.howToFix: Ensure the string is not empty before indexing. Use `len(str) > 0` to check first.

E11001.howToFix: Ensure the time string matches the expected format. Check for typos in the date/time string.

E12001.usedFor: Using non-hashable type (array, map, struct) as map key
E12001.example: map key must be a hashable type, got ARRAY
E12001.howToFix: Map keys must be hashable types: `string`, `int`, `float`, `bool`, or `char`. Arrays and maps cannot be keys.

E12002.usedFor: Attempting to modify a const map
E12002.example: cannot modify immutable map (declared as const)
E12002.howToFix: Use `var` instead of `const` for the map if you need to modify it.

E12003.howToFix: Check if the key exists using `maps.contains(m, key)` before accessing.

E12004.usedFor: Invalid format when creating a map from entries
E12004.example: map entry must be a [key, value] pair
E12004.howToFix: Ensure each map entry is a two-element array containing [key, value].

E12005.usedFor: Using maps.invert() when values are not hashable types
E12005.example: map value is not hashable and cannot become a key
E12005.howToFix: Map keys must be hashable (string, int, float, bool, char). Values like arrays, maps, or structs cannot become keys.

W1001.example: variable 'x' is declared but never used
W1001.howToFix: Use the variable, remove it, or suppress with `#suppress(W1001)`.

W1002.example: module 'math' is imported but never used
W1002.howToFix: Use the imported module or remove the import.

W1003.example: function 'helper' is declared but never called
W1003.howToFix: Call the function or remove it.

W1004.usedFor: Function parameter never referenced in body
W1004.example: parameter 'x' is declared but never used
W1004.howToFix: Use the parameter, prefix with `_` to indicate intentionally unused, or suppress with `#suppress(W1004)`.

W2001.howToFix: Remove the unreachable code or restructure your control flow. Suppress with `#suppress(W2001)`.
W2001.suppressible: Suppress with #suppress(W2001) at function declaration site OR #suppress(ALL) at top of file

W2002.usedFor: Inner scope variable with same name as outer
W2002.example: variable 'x' shadows variable in outer scope
W2002.howToFix: Rename the inner variable to avoid confusion, or suppress with `#suppress(W2002)`.

W2003.usedFor: Function with return type but no return
W2003.example: Function 'foo' declares return type(s) but has no return statement
W2003.howToFix: Ensure all code paths return a value, or suppress with `#suppress(W2003)`.
W2003.suppressible: Suppress with #suppress(W2003) at function declaration site OR #suppress(ALL) at top of file

W2004.example: implicit conversion from int to float
W2004.howToFix: Use explicit type conversion to make the intent clear, or suppress with `#suppress(W2004)`.

W2005.usedFor: Use of deprecated syntax or function
W2005.howToFix: Update to use the recommended alternative, or suppress with `#suppress(W2005)`.

W2006.usedFor: Arithmetic on byte values that may exceed 0-255 range
W2006.example: byte arithmetic may overflow: result could exceed 255
W2006.howToFix: Ensure byte arithmetic results stay within 0-255 range, or use a larger integer type.

W3001.howToFix: Add code to the block, add a comment explaining why it's empty, or suppress with `#suppress(W3001)`.

W3002.howToFix: Simplify your condition or remove the check entirely. Suppress with `#suppress(W3002)`.

W3003.usedFor: Declaring a fixed-size array but providing fewer elements than the declared size
W3003.example: array declared with size 10 but only 3 elements provided
W3003.howToFix: Initialize all elements of a fixed-size array, or suppress with `#suppress(W3003)`.
W3003.suppressible: Suppress with #suppress(W3003) at function declaration site OR #suppress(ALL) at top of file

W4001.usedFor: Warning when module declaration name differs from directory name
W4001.example: module name 'foo' does not match directory name 'bar'
W4001.howToFix: Rename the module to match the directory name, or rename the directory.
